docs.snippet: BLASS--Norman. Devoted husband of 59 years to loving wife, Jaclyn, nee Gilder; wonderful father to Michael, Jon and Peter; treasured grandfather of Alex, Zachary, Amanda and Josh; supportive brother to Harvey. Passed peacefully May 2 in West Palm ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BLASS--Norman. Devoted husband of 59 years to loving wife, Jaclyn, nee Gilder; wonderful father to Michael, Jon and Peter; treasured grandfather of Alex, Zachary, Amanda and Josh; supportive brother to Harvey. Passed peacefully May 2 in West Palm Beach. An attorney for 60 years, he was a pioneering sports agent for dozens of basketball players. A graduate of Syracuse University and Fordham Law, he served in the Army in World War II. Longtime member of the Friars, and contributor to many charities. He will be missed. Funeral May 6, 10am, graveside at Union Field Cemetery, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, NY.

docs.snippet: Who has the better ideas: Larry Summers, who helped design U.S. economic policy under two Democratic presidents, or Glenn Hubbard, George W. Bush’s tax-cutting guru?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Who has the better ideas: Larry Summers, who helped design U.S. economic policy under two Democratic presidents, or Glenn Hubbard, George W. Bush’s tax-cutting guru?
docs.abstract: Adam Davidson article compares different economic views espoused by two influential economists: Larry Summers, who helped design America's modern economic policy under Pres Clinton and Pres Obama, and Glenn Hubbard, George W Bush's tax-cutting guru.

headline.seo: Larry Summers and Glenn Hubbard Square Off on Our Economic Future

docs.lead_paragraph: A centerpiece of an overhaul of the juvenile justice system gives New York City’s young delinquents, like Mone’t, 17, local options for rehabilitation.
docs.abstract: Program called Close to Home, centerpiece of juvenile justice system overhaul, gives New York City’s young delinquents local options for rehabilitation, allowing them to remain close to their families; success of program for 17-year-old girl, identified only as Mo'net, described.

headline.seo: Program Keeps Troubled New York Youth Close to Home
